articles.headline: 25 Years After War, Wealth Changes Falklands
articles.snippet: The British-controlled islands in the South Atlantic are facing an influx of outsiders attracted by new prosperity.
articles.abstract: The British-controlled islands in the South Atlantic are facing an influx of outsiders attracted by new prosperity.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANLEY, Falkland Islands — Twenty-five years ago, Argentina invaded this wind-swept cluster of British-controlled islands in the remote South Atlantic. After 11 weeks of combat that claimed nearly 1,000 lives, British troops drove off the occupiers, allowing the islanders to continue with their eminently British way of life.

articles.headline: Borrowing Trouble
articles.snippet: A class-action suit tests the practices of NovaStar Financial, a mortgage lender based in Kansas City, Mo.
articles.abstract: A class-action suit tests the practices of NovaStar Financial, a mortgage lender based in Kansas City, Mo.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gregory and Paula Sherman wanted to refinance the mortgage on their ranch-style home in Chattaroy, Wash., near Spokane, in June 2003, they went to a local mortgage broker.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: A Map for the Maze of Federal Contracts
articles.snippet: Many small-business owners find the process of securing a federal supply contract frustrating.
articles.abstract: Many small-business owners find the process of securing a federal supply contract frustrating.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARL R. BONITZ is co-owner of a small business, and he wants a piece of the federal contracting pie.

articles.headline: New Bar Codes Can Talk With Your Cellphone
articles.snippet: Software will let phones read encoded data on everyday objects to call up videos, pictures or text from the Internet.
articles.abstract: Software will let phones read encoded data on everyday objects to call up videos, pictures or text from the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like something straight out of a futuristic film: House hunters, driving past a for-sale sign, stop and point their cellphone at the sign. With a click, their cellphone screen displays the asking price, the number of bedrooms and baths and lots of other details about the house.

articles.headline: The End of the Line as Detroit Workers Know It
articles.snippet: Detroit’s displaced are struggling to build new lives.
articles.abstract: Detroit’s displaced are struggling to build new lives.

articles.headline: Israel Warns of Hamas Military Buildup in Gaza
articles.snippet: The Palestinian faction is building tunnels and bunkers and smuggling in missiles and explosives, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Palestinian faction is building tunnels and bunkers and smuggling in missiles and explosives, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, March 31 — Hamas, the dominant faction in the Palestinian government, is building its military capacity in the Gaza Strip, constructing tunnels and underground bunkers and smuggling in ground-to-air missiles and military-grade explosives, senior Israeli officials say.

articles.headline: Cold Reality in Some Hot I.P.O.’s
articles.snippet: To anyone with a memory going back more than five minutes, this year’s ratio of profitable to unprofitable I.P.O.’s is something of a danger sign.
articles.abstract: To anyone with a memory going back more than five minutes, this year’s ratio of profitable to unprofitable I.P.O.’s is something of a danger sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOULD you rather own stock in a company that is profitable or one that is merely promotable? Lately, investors buying initial public offerings have chosen sizzle more than steak.

articles.headline: Warner’s Digital Watchdog Widens War on Pirates
articles.snippet: Warner’s technology executives are at the forefront of the movie industry as they try to protect the studio’s control over its content.
articles.abstract: Warner’s technology executives are at the forefront of the movie industry as they try to protect the studio’s control over its content.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 1 — Hollywood studios spend millions every year trying to get people to watch their movies. At Warner Brothers Entertainment, Darcy Antonellis is trying to get them to stop watching — illegally, that is.

articles.headline: Pushing a New Writer Upstream
articles.snippet: More publishers are finding the pre-publication book tour as an indispensable part of their marketing plan.
articles.abstract: More publishers are finding the pre-publication book tour as an indispensable part of their marketing plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At a table with a half-dozen enraptured Borders executives in a private room at the French bistro Mon Amí Gabi, between sips of Côtes du Rhône, the fledgling British novelist Steven Hall began telling the Nicole Kidman story.

articles.headline: Stalking Strangers’ DNA to Fill in the Family Tree
articles.snippet: Inexpensive genetic testing is turning the once-staid pursuit of genealogy into an extreme sport.
articles.abstract: Inexpensive genetic testing is turning the once-staid pursuit of genealogy into an extreme sport.
articles.lead_paragraph: They swab the cheeks of strangers and pluck hairs from corpses. They travel hundreds of miles to entice their suspects with an old photograph, or sometimes a free drink. Cooperation is preferred, but not necessarily required to achieve their ends.

articles.headline: Thousands Are Laid Off at Circuit City. What’s New?
articles.snippet: Media outlets could not be blamed for having a little fatigue when it comes to layoffs. But with Circuit City, there are larger issues.
articles.abstract: Media outlets could not be blamed for having a little fatigue when it comes to layoffs. But with Circuit City, there are larger issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: When executives at Circuit City decided last Wednesday to cut costs by laying off 3,400 of their most experienced salesclerks, they undoubtedly went through a number of calculations: that they could save $250 million over two years; that consumers are inured to bad service; and that the layoffs would be a one-day blip in the news.

articles.headline: Some Hospitals Call 911 to Save Their Patients
articles.snippet: A recent case has raised  questions about the ability of small hospitals to care for patients who suffer complications.
articles.abstract: A recent case has raised  questions about the ability of small hospitals to care for patients who suffer complications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should a hospital be able to handle a medical emergency?

articles.headline: Old Church Becomes Mosque in Uneasy Britain
articles.snippet: A battle to turn a former Christian church into a mosque underscored Britain’s unease with its Muslim minority.
articles.abstract: A battle to turn a former Christian church into a mosque underscored Britain’s unease with its Muslim minority.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLITHEROE, England — On a chilly night this winter, this pristine town in some of Britain’s most untouched countryside voted to allow a former Christian church to become a mosque.

articles.headline: Speculation Is in the Air Over EMI and Apple
articles.snippet: The announcement of a joint news conference to be held in London on Monday set off a torrent of speculation.
articles.abstract: The announcement of a joint news conference to be held in London on Monday set off a torrent of speculation.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 1 — Relations between Apple Inc. and the EMI Group, once at odds over the trademark rights to the Apple name, the record label of the Beatles, seem to be getting better all the time.

articles.headline: Qaeda Is Seen as Restoring Leadership
articles.snippet: A new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the network’s operations, officials said.
articles.abstract: A new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the network’s operations, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — As Al Qaeda rebuilds in Pakistan’s tribal areas, a new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the network’s operations, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.

articles.headline: A Salute for His Wounded, a Last Touch for His Dead
articles.snippet: In Iraq’s increasingly violent Diyala Province, the Third Brigade Combat Team of the First Cavalry Division has seen 39 soldiers die in five months.
articles.abstract: In Iraq’s increasingly violent Diyala Province, the Third Brigade Combat Team of the First Cavalry Division has seen 39 soldiers die in five months.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq, March 31 — In the last moments of his life, Sgt. First Class Benjamin L. Sebban saw the flatbed truck speed into the concertina wire guarding his small Army patrol base near Baquba.
